body: Also I want to add some more tests before this is merged -- seems like the kernel.js and session.js are somewhat minimal at the moment.
Updated to include more tests and add back in support for the query string for `Kernel.start`.
Ok, I made a few more minor changes and added better documentation. I think I'm happy with where this is now!
As there seem to be some interest in having docs, [this](https://www.npmjs.org/package/jsdoc-rst-template) seem pretty recent and export js docs  to sphinx.
Ooh, cool. Yeah, it would be great if we had autogenerated docs for the javascript API in addition to the python api.

I think this introduces some issues with notifications, which aren't really being tested currently. I think before this is merged I should add some tests for checking that they do or do not show (including modal dialogs too).

> I think before this is merged I should add some tests

Music to my ears.
I'm sorry; but it needs rebase :-(
Yeah, that's ok, I am adding more tests and stuff anyway so no problem.

Ok, this has been rebased and I added a lot more tests. In particular, I added a new type of test case, `event_test`, that takes a list of event names and an action that should trigger them and tests that they are received in order. I also created this page on the wiki, for referencing the various event types: https://github.com/ipython/ipython/wiki/Dev:-Javascript-Events

There are still two cases that I want to test that I don't know how to, though:
1. When the frontend `Kernel` object gets a status message saying that the kernel is restarting (i.e. it is "autorestarting")
2. When the frontend `Kernel` object gets a status message saying that the kernel is dead

Is there a way I can trigger the kernel to send these two types of messages, so I can test how the frontend handles them?

> When the frontend Kernel object gets a status message saying that the kernel is restarting (i.e. it is "autorestarting")

You should be able to trigger this by executing `os._exit(1)`

> When the frontend Kernel object gets a status message saying that the kernel is dead

I think you can accomplish this by making the connection file invalid before killing the kernel:

``` python
import os
from IPython.kernel.connect import get_connection_file
with open(get_connection_file(), 'w') as f:
    f.write("garbage")
os._exit(1)
```
Great. I added tests for those things, so this should be ready for review again I think!

Looks fine. I just have one concern about hidding all modals if ever there is a modal that could be already opened that really would need the user to do an action. But if this is the case we can still attach a `onclose` event to it that is sure to trigger the callback.

+1

Hmm, yeah, I hadn't thought about that case. The reason why I close them is because otherwise the experience is kind of weird when the kernel dies and can't be restarted -- first it pops up the dialog saying "the kernel has died and will restart automatically" and then when it eventually gives up it shows another dialog saying "the kernel has died and needs to be manually restarted". If the first dialog isn't closed, then, the second one is shown behind the first one and they won't see it until they click ok on the first one. Additionally, the gray backdrop stacks, so the background gets darker for each additional dialog.

Maybe it could be, only close dialogs that are kernel-related, and if there are other dialogs open, leave them be?

> Maybe it could be, only close dialogs that are kernel-related, and if there are other dialogs open, leave them be?

Yeah, I guess that could be doable I suppose we can even "mutate" the content of the current dialog to show "restarting attempt 1... 2.... 3...4... 5 \n blah blah blah" but that's kind of a weird UI. Unless maybe the element are there at the beginning, but greyed and unhide progressively (Just thinking at loud).

> Maybe it could be, only close dialogs that are kernel-related, and if there are other dialogs open, leave them be?

We can add a `kernel_dialog` class to kernel-related modals.

This is _awesome_. I think there is probably a similar project to think carefully about how to deal with reconnecting when the connection is lost in a variety of ways, but that doesn't need to be done here.

I notice you have some `kernel_event.Kernel` and some `status_event.Kernel`. What's the distinction? One logical boundary would be that only msgspec status messages trigger `status_event`s, but that isn't the case at the moment.

> We can add a kernel_dialog class to kernel-related modals.

Great idea!

> This is awesome.

Thanks! :smile: 

> I notice you have some kernel_event.Kernel and some status_event.Kernel. What's the distinction? 

I don' think there's a super obvious one. I think both existed before and I sort of just went with that. Now that you bring it up, though, it might be good to just rename all the `status_event` to `kernel_event` to be consistent.

> One logical boundary would be that only msgspec status messages trigger status_events, but that isn't the case at the moment.

Yeah, I don't think there's any way to get around having the frontend trigger status messages sometimes -- for example, it can detect that the kernel is dead but never actually get a status message about it being dead.
Ok, changed it so it keeps trying to reconnect; fixed the stuff with modals; made the event naming more consistent.
Ok, now I'm confused with this/that. I believe it is that in some places that have closure, but I don't know if this is ok too. Getting late. Need sleep. C U tomorrow, things might be clearer.

Ah, no, you're totally right, it should be `that`. Gah, Javascript. There was no problem because none of the functions that get that event actually check the arguments. I guess I should test for that, too ;)
Ok, bugs with this/that should be fixed now.
:-( I think it needs a rebase now. Sorry.
Ok, rebased.

Ok, I've been running with this PR for the last few days and haven't noticed any obvious bugs. Since it's fairly large, though, it would probably be good if other people tested it out too, in case I've missed anything.
I'll have a last read and merge so that the highest number can test.
Ok, let's try.
Thanks!
